prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Imaging requirements: Based on previous PdBI, VLA, and ALMA observations of FIR-bright quasars, our objects are expected to be compact with angular size ca. 0.5". To maximize the detection sensitivity, we ask for observations in a compact configuration.
Sensitivity requirements: We base the required continuum sensitivity, sigma=50 micro Jy, on the stacking analysis of Wang et al. (2008), which showed that for MAMBO non-detected sources the average flux is ca. 0.5mJy at 250 GHz. In order to detect most of the sources in our sample, we require that an object as faint as a third of the average would be detectable at the 3 sigma-level, corresponding to L(FIR) = 7e11 L_solar.
[CII] was detected in 14 z>5 quasars (almost all detected by our group) that have line fluxes 1$-$5 Jy km/s with a median 1.5 Jy km/s, FWHM 400 km/s, and line peak 4 mJy. Based on this we adjust the line sensitivity to expect detections for most targets. Given the redshift uncertainty, we must identify a line at >4sigma in 3 resolution elements. With our chosen sensitivity of 0.5 mJy per 100 km/s bin we detect the median observed quasar at 8sigma over 4 resolution elements (which can well trace the line profile given the 35 km/s spectral resolution), and the faintest yet observed (J1120+0641 at z=7.1, 4 mJy x 235 km/s) at 8sigma over 2 resolution elements. This corresponds to a detection limit of L([CII])= 6e8 L_sun.
Correlator setup: Most of our spectroscopic targets have very reliable MgII redshifts abs(z(MgII)-z(CO))< 0.01, (Wang et al. 2010), the others have redshifts from rest-UV spectral fits, with delta z approximately 0.03. With a contiguous bandwidth of 3.75 GHz in the upper SB we can search for [CII] over a redshift range of 0.1 at z=6, which is sufficient to comfortably cover any redshift uncertainty.
We will use the dual polarization, maximum bandwidth correlator mode yielding 7.5GHz total effective bandwidth.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Optically-selected quasars have been detected well into the dark ages, indicating the existence of supermassive black holes (SMBH) within a Gyr of the Big Bang and providing strong constraints on the growth of SMBHs and on their host galaxies. FIR continuum and line observations reveal that the quasar hosts show intense star formation and massive, enriched dense gas reservoirs. By observing 15 new quasars at z>5.8 we propose to significantly expand the number of quasar submm continuum and [CII] detections at these early epochs, reaching a significant sample spanning a factor 15 in quasar bolometric luminosity, 40 in BH mass, and 100 in FIR luminosity. We can thereby study whether all high-z quasars are associated with starbursts, quantify any correlation between SMBH accretion and star formation, and the origin of the dust masses. [CII] observations will provide insights on the host dynamics, merger history, feedback, and on cosmic reionization. ALMA has the power to put past, biased studies on a more representative footing, in order to quantify the relationship between SMBH growth and star formation and further our understanding of the formation of galaxies in the early universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
